text:
Hundreds of protesters gathered on Bridge Street on June 6, as part of a wave
of demonstrations after the death of George Floyd.

Floyd was a 46-year-old Minneapolis man whose death during an arrest for
allegedly using counterfeit money sparked protests against police brutality
and racial injustice throughout the country.

The Charlevoix event was organized on Facebook by long-time resident Sarah
Polena-Antinossi in less than a week's time with help from Boyne City resident
Jessica Oppermann.

"When George Floyd called out for his mama because he knew he was dying, that
was it for me. That was when I realized that I can't sit behind my phone
screen anymore. I need to do something. I need to be an ally. I need to be a
voice. I need to use the privilege of my skin color to stand up for and stand
next to people and help them," said Polena-Antinossi, a 1997 Charlevoix High
School graduate.

On the day of the demonstration, Polena-Antinossi was one of several
participants that carried a sign reading, "All mothers were summoned when he
called out for his mama. #GeorgeFloyd."

Polena-Antinossi reached out to Charlevoix police chief Gerard Doan prior to
the event to ensure coordination with the police department.

At her request, Doan and a few other officers attended the event, sitting
across the street in police vehicles or standing on the sidewalk.

"We kept the line of communication open," said Doan. "She came over and talked
to me a couple of times during the event and I went over and talked to her a
couple of times."

Doan said aside from a few people driving by yelling obscenities at the
protesters there was no trouble that resulted from the demonstration and all
participants were respectfully not blocking the sidewalks or streets.

"She did a lot of homework on her own ahead of time. She did a lot of
research. She went on the city website and looked at the ordinances - you
can't block city sidewalks, or use loud speaker devices ... a great deal of
the homework was already done ahead of time so that her and I just kind of
brainstormed a few things and she had everything ready to go. It was a very
smooth operation," Doan said.

Doan said Saturday's demonstration was the largest he has seen in Charlevoix
in the 34 years he has been with the force. Doan has been Charlevoix's police
chief since 2006.

Two separate rallies were held on June 6; the first from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. and
the second from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. At the halfway point during each rally, the
organizers asked the crowd to kneel for eight minutes and 46 seconds - the
amount of time that officer Derrick Chauvin pressed his knee into Floyd's
neck.

During the second rally, the kneeling protesters stretched from Antrim Street
to Clinton Street in front of East Park.

Coinciding with Charlevoix's demonstration, a number of protests occurred
across the country on Saturday, including Washington, D.C.'s largest protest
so far in which tens of thousands of people participated and security forces
blocked any approach to the White House, according to the Washington Post.

When asked if he or his team has felt any backlash during this time, Chief
Doan said just the opposite - that the Charlevoix police department has felt
appreciation from the community.

"We had a lot of folks come up to us during the event and thank us for doing
our job. They said they appreciate the job that our officers do in our town
and in the area. Lots of people approached us and thanked us for what we did,
which was very humbling," Doan said.

title: Downtown Charlevoix protest draws hundreds
html:
Hundreds of protesters gathered on Bridge Street on June 6, as part of a wave of demonstrations after the death of George Floyd.

Floyd was a 46-year-old Minneapolis man whose death during an arrest for allegedly using counterfeit money sparked protests against police brutality and racial injustice throughout the country.

The Charlevoix event was organized on Facebook by long-time resident Sarah Polena-Antinossi in less than a week's time with help from Boyne City resident Jessica Oppermann.

"When George Floyd called out for his mama because he knew he was dying, that was it for me. That was when I realized that I can't sit behind my phone screen anymore. I need to do something. I need to be an ally. I need to be a voice. I need to use the privilege of my skin color to stand up for and stand next to people and help them," said Polena-Antinossi, a 1997 Charlevoix High School graduate.

On the day of the demonstration, Polena-Antinossi was one of several participants that carried a sign reading, "All mothers were summoned when he called out for his mama. #GeorgeFloyd."

Polena-Antinossi reached out to Charlevoix police chief Gerard Doan prior to the event to ensure coordination with the police department.

At her request, Doan and a few other officers attended the event, sitting across the street in police vehicles or standing on the sidewalk.

"We kept the line of communication open," said Doan. "She came over and talked to me a couple of times during the event and I went over and talked to her a couple of times."

Doan said aside from a few people driving by yelling obscenities at the protesters there was no trouble that resulted from the demonstration and all participants were respectfully not blocking the sidewalks or streets.

"She did a lot of homework on her own ahead of time. She did a lot of research. She went on the city website and looked at the ordinances - you can't block city sidewalks, or use loud speaker devices ... a great deal of the homework was already done ahead of time so that her and I just kind of brainstormed a few things and she had everything ready to go. It was a very smooth operation," Doan said.

Doan said Saturday's demonstration was the largest he has seen in Charlevoix in the 34 years he has been with the force. Doan has been Charlevoix's police chief since 2006.

Two separate rallies were held on June 6; the first from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. and the second from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. At the halfway point during each rally, the organizers asked the crowd to kneel for eight minutes and 46 seconds - the amount of time that officer Derrick Chauvin pressed his knee into Floyd's neck.

During the second rally, the kneeling protesters stretched from Antrim Street to Clinton Street in front of East Park.

Coinciding with Charlevoix's demonstration, a number of protests occurred across the country on Saturday, including Washington, D.C.'s largest protest so far in which tens of thousands of people participated and security forces blocked any approach to the White House, according to the Washington Post.

When asked if he or his team has felt any backlash during this time, Chief Doan said just the opposite - that the Charlevoix police department has felt appreciation from the community.

"We had a lot of folks come up to us during the event and thank us for doing our job. They said they appreciate the job that our officers do in our town and in the area. Lots of people approached us and thanked us for what we did, which was very humbling," Doan said.
